channel.title: C# documentation
channel.description:
Since I'm working as a student employee at an IT company I now have to document my code. Since this is the first time I have to document code I'm wondering if I'm doing it right, I'm not sure whether there are some specific rules to follow or not.
Is this piece of code well-documentated or not? If not, what could I do better? http://pastebin.com/wnyPP6LQ

item.title: C# documentation
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

That code is awful. In my experience if you have to write comments inside a function then it’s doing too much.
One method should do one thing.

And what’s up with the error handling? Surely not being able to reach a service endpoint of some kind is exceptional behaviour that warrants not swallowing the exception.

Read full topic

item.title: C# documentation
item.dc:creator: @pure2ownage Pure_
item.description:
@pure2ownage wrote:

[quote=“Tree, post:5, topic:552969”]Also, here’s a tool that got me through most of my units when I was short on time and needed commenting. Obviously it isn’t recommended on crucial sections but it’s useful when you’re short on time.

http://www.atomineerutils.com/[/quote]holy shit this is amazing

i use sandcastle to gen my docs from the vs xml output format

Read full topic

item.title: C# documentation
item.dc:creator: @Protosstribe object
item.description:
@Protosstribe wrote:

Also, you should write full documentation. The part "When false is returned, the client is told to delete the " doesn’t really tell me anything. What’s supposed to be deleted?

Other than that, I really prefer Javadocs to C#-documentation. It’s pretty hard to read the XML-like syntax of C#-documentation. This is probably just me though, so nothing you should really care about.

Read full topic

item.title: C# documentation
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

I would also use xml-doc. See https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/5ast78ax(v=vs.140).aspx for a list of the tags you can use.

Read full topic

item.title: C# documentation
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

That’s funny, I experienced the complete opposite in all of the places I worked after graduating. Maybe it’s supposed to be self-documenting…

One thing I would say is that you should try making your comments more concise and think about what another programmer would want to know at that level. For example, instead of “A bool to check if the transmission was successfull. False when flooding or when the Aucxis service is offline.”, maybe just “True if transmission was successful, otherwise false”. If the programmer needs to know this information it’s too much for a bool imo, and should be a more self-documenting return type.

I think naming should also be a bit more consistent? Doesn’t matter here so much, but I think in general it’s good to be more precise especially when you have more complex stuff it’s annoying for other people to work it all out. For example, the function is called “Send” but the comments refer to it as “passing”.

Other than that it seems pretty good - I can understand what the code is doing, and it goes into just the right about of detail… explaining things that aren’t immediately obvious by reading the code, and without going into detail about irrelevant shit that I could just work out myself if I really wanted to.

Read full topic
